War is coming, and your citizens can ill-afford to cower in your Mediterranean stronghold. The obvious target is to unite Sicily under your banner, but to do so will mean war with Carthage. They command a powerful empire, but should you be successful against them then their territory on the African mainland is yours for the taking. The Romans to the north are strong and their lands are rich; war with them will be a high-stakes game but is inevitable if you are to secure your empire. To the east lies Greece, your spiritual homeland. Trading partners may be sought there for now, but your long-term goal in the area should be conquest. Greek culture is destined to dominate the Mediterranean; Syracuse shall see it done!

Your people are to be found at the end of the world. War is coming, however, and no land shall be spared; you are to conquer or be conquered. The Celtici maintain a fortress to the south, and if you seek expansion then war with them is inevitable. Its walls are high, but your warriors are strong, so pick your moment to strike! Further afield, a number of other tribal lands lay ready for conquest. If Iberia is to become your stronghold then they must all bow to you. Your people did not ask for war, but if war it is to be then the world will learn the strength of the Lusitani!

Iberia is a land, of proud, good people, none moreso than yours. Barring the Lusitani your relations with the tribes surrounding yours remain strong in the face of foreign aggression. The Turdetani to the south find themselves hard-pressed by the Carthaginian invaders. They may appreciate your assistance, or you may decide to seize their lands yourself. To the west, the warlike Lusitani remain a thorn in the side of Iberian co-operation, and should be eliminated sooner rather than later. Beyond the seas great powers rise to threaten your peoples, and you may seek to unite the tribes of Iberia behind your banner to survive. Come what may, the Arevaci will prevail!
War with Rome has come again! Finally!
Our recent capture of Saguntum has cut the last bind of peace between our peoples. Rome will know only suffering from this day forth.
In time, our armies will swarm across all Italy. Rome's allies will bow to Carthage or face annihilation alongside their Latin masters.
Our home city in Africa may be secure, but as the majority of our forces are abroad we must be wary of an enemy strike against it.
In Iberia, further gains must be made. The land is rich in silver to aid our war against Rome.
It is over twenty years since war last raged across Sicily.
Since its defeat, Carthage’s gaze has turned towards Iberia, making great profits there.
Now a Carthaginian general named Hannibal Barca has sacked Saguntum, a valued ally of Rome. War can be your only response.
The battleground of Iberia is ripe for conquest. Great riches can be found in her mines and manpower. Those riches should belong to Rome.
Our diplomats can join the offensive. If the allies of Carthage can be persuaded to break away, our army’s task will be all the easier.
The Mediterranean will belong to Rome! Carthage must be destroyed!
We are the great survivors. Despite the devastation of Sicily through years of war, our city has prospered as an ally of Rome.
However, that alliance should persist only whilst it serves our benefit. Whilst Rome and Carthage are once again preoccupied with each other, Syracuse will carve out its own space in the world.
With little room to manoeuvre, we must choose our allies carefully. Continuing our alliance with Rome would allow us to focus on north Africa and the gains to be made there.
Switching sides, however, would free Syracuse to capture territory on Sicily and the Italian mainland. Carthage would no doubt be very interested in an ally so close to Roman territory.
The stakes could not be higher, and it is time for Syracuse to place a bet.
Our homeland, a timeless country of hills and pasture, can be found at the very edge of the world. We would have it no other way.
Though we do not seek conflict, word reaches us that foreign powers are encroaching upon our neighbours’ lands. We must protect our people and prepare for war!
The Galleaci to the north could be useful allies, but the income from their mines would better serve our cause if we controlled it directly...
The Celtici to the south are weak pawns of Carthage. They forfeited their lands the day they made peace with the invaders.
We have traditionally stood apart from the affairs of outsiders, but events have forced our hands. Now the world will know the strength of the Lusitani!
War comes uninvited. Our high country now finds itself surrounded by Carthage and its puppet tribes. To hesitate now will mean destruction.
With Carthage and Rome engaged in bitter conflict there are three options open to us: ally with Carthage in their war against Rome, join Rome and fight against Carthage, or stand against both!
If we choose the latter, we must seek an alliance with the Celtic tribes to the northwest, but such an arrangement is risky - Arevaci lands would be the frontline of any such conflict.
The world has thrust war upon us, but now it will witness the fury of the Arevaci!
It is time for Carthage to ascend and dominate the Mediterranean! Ba'al-Hammon be praised!

A compatible Touch device has been detected. Touch controls can be used to move the camera, give orders to units on the battlefield, control armies on the campaign map, navigate through menus and much more. An on screen keyboard can be activated via the option in the controls menu. For more information, please click [[url:/manual/single-player/0005_enc_page_help_keyboard_shortcuts]]here[[/url]] to view the Touch controls page in the encyclopaedia.

Your people are of strong, Celtic blood, but they are recent migrants to these lands and find themselves surrounded by strangers and enemies. To the west stand the Macedonians, an ambitious people whose aggression has led them to seek war with you. They covet your lands, but they will learn of your strength the hard way. To the north lies the Odrysian Kingdom. Beware their growing ambitions on land and at sea, but they may be useful as allies against Macedon, for now. Across the Bosphorus, the Bithynians hold no love for you. If taken, their fortress city would connect your lands to those of the Galatians, fellow Celts who have settled in the east. Your people must fight to survive, but that has always been your way. From your new home the riches of the civilised world are yours to raid and conquer!

The varied peoples of Thrace have united under your banner, and they look to you for leadership in an uncertain world. The belligerence of the Macedonians to the southeast threatens war. Should it come, your people must be prepared, so you must ready  your forces. The warlike Triballi to the west pose a similar threat, and their aggression must be kept in check. To the south, Tylis is vulnerable. Their war with Macedon may make them useful allies, or it may distract attention if you decide to break your treaty and strike. Across the Danube River, The Getae may be your kin, but their ultimate ambitions are unknown. There may be profit in co-operation, but they must be watched carefully. It is time for your people to ascend as a great nation, for history to record the rise of the Odrysian Kingdom!

For centuries your people have defended their homes against invaders. Now is the right time to start fighting back. Along the coast are the nomadic Scythians, towards whom natural enmity has developed following centuries of incursions. Their warriors are skilled on horseback, but weak on foot or by sea, so you must take the fight to them there. You have friends in central Dacia, but if you wish to expand your territory these alliances will inevitably come under tension. The Triballi to the south have few friends and many enemies, and their lands could surely be yours in time. However, an invasion would mean crossing the Odrysian Kingdom; it will have to be subdued, either by diplomacy or force. Such will be the fate of all the world: all shall kneel before the might of the Getae!

Your people make their living from the sea, and it is by sea that your power will spread. You have prospered by exacting tolls from the vessels of others, but this has earned you enemies. The Delmatae to the north are hostile to your raids upon their shipping. Should your struggle with them erupt into war you may find an ally in the Daorsi, who are no allies of the Delmatae. Across the sea lies Rome and the Etruscan League. They will not stand by whilst your influence in the Adriatic grows unchecked, so prepare for war. To the south, the archaic powers in Greece squabble relentlessly with one another. In time, your power will eclipse them all. The sea will lend the Ardiaei access to every corner of the world. All shall know of your power!

For centuries your people have prospered on these strange and foreign shores, trading wares and civilised ideals with the natives. War looms, however, and you must take up arms to ensure their survival. Of the nearby barbarian tribes, the Helvetii are the most belligerent. They must be watched, but beware of provoking war prematurely, as they have many allies to the east. To the west, the Volcae are vulnerable, and expansion here may gain you an Atlantic port. Such versatility will serve you well in the coming struggle for the Mediterranean. The scions of Greece are destined to rule the world! Massilia shall conquer all!

This is barbarian country, the natives known for war and human sacrifice. Despite this, your people have prospered here, but success has earned you enemies. The Siraces to the east remain hostile to your presence. Strike soon, while they remain pre-occupied with their war against the Aorsoi. You are at peace with the Scythians to the north, but they are untrustworthy and must be neutralised, one way or another. To the south lies open water, your dominance of which is challenged by the great kingdom of Pontus. Your war with them is ongoing, but once they are beaten the sea will be yours to command. History shall record the rise of Cimmeria!

Yours is a land of ancient legend, the country of Troy and the Iliad. Your heritage offers little protection against foreign invasion, however; you must defend yourself or be destroyed. The Sardes to the east - the decadent people of Croesus - are your principal foes. Seek allies: both Bithynia to the north and Rhodes to the south are predisposed towards you, and may be amenable to military co-operation. Further allies around the Aegean will be hard to come by, so maintain your defences, especially against the larger regional powers of Macedon and the Seleucids. Destiny awaits the people of Pergamon! The world shall be yours!

This land, this mythical country of the Golden Fleece your people call home, is found at the very edge of the Greek-speaking world. Barbarian cultures surround you, but with the Caucasus mountains at your back your primary enemies stand to the south. Trapezos are longstanding rivals, and should be your first target for expansion. Further west lies the powerful Kingdom of Pontus, which you must confront if you wish to dominate the sea. However, you may choose instead to send your forces inland, where they will meet resistance from Armenia. War may come to Colchis, but your might will be known the length of the civilised world!

After years living under the yoke of foreign rule you are at last free to rebuild your kingdom. The former Persian lands, shattered by Alexander, lie unprotected and vulnerable - ensure you are the one who profits from this. A rapid conclusion to your war with Ardhan is essential, and you may wish to forge an alliance with the friendly Pontians to this end. With enough haste you may even be able to subjugate those who denied your liberty, as Media Atropatene have granted you permission to march your armies through their territories and into the heart of Persia. Such a reversal of fate will be glorious indeed! It is your destiny to take back what is yours and carve a new Kingdom of Armenia for posterity!

With care, you may yet nurture a mighty empire from the fragment handed down to you. Ultimately, your goal should be to break free from the Roman yoke, but for now their enmity with the Parthians will prove useful. Rome will surely support your attempts to conquer your old enemy, and Parthia’s ally, Media Atropatene. Alternatively, you could leave your foes to wipe each other out and focus on the expansion of your other borders. With the help of your Pontic neighbours, your former territories on the Caspian shores could also be reclaimed. Greatness is in your grasp. Rise again, Armenia!

Egypt’s present may be a pale imitation of its past glory, but its future greatness is in your hands. You must restore your ancient holdings in Africa and the east. Your greatest ally in this endeavour will be the Roman general, Mark Antony. He will deal with the ever-expansionist Parthians, enabling you to turn and dispatch the troublesome Nasamones nomads to the west. While Judea and Nabatea remain Antony’s protectorates, east Africa and Arabia will be yours for the taking. However, be ever mindful of Lepidus lurking in the west, as once the Triumvirate breaks down he may seek to add Egypt to his African domain. This must not be allowed to happen; ensure that the Champions of Ma’at are ever victorious!

You are the best hope for a united Britannia. The Corieltauvi are your old enemies, a constant source of dissent between tribes that must be silenced. Even then, do not expect the rest to bow before you without a fight. You will need the support of your Dumnonii allies to stand any chance of taming such fiercely independent people. Yet the rewards will be great; trouble is brewing in the Roman homelands and their weakening grip will present many opportunities for conquest. Go forth, be lord of all Britannia and many more lands to the south. Unite and conquer!

As the most powerful force in the east, you are the spiritual successor to the many proud empires of old. Roman expansion has put pressure on your lands, and now Mark Antony brings war to the very heart of your empire. Remember, however, that the Roman Triumvirate, of which he is a member, is fragile at best. An early defeat will make Mark Antony a tempting target for the other two. Alternatively, you may focus your efforts on expanding in other directions until the Triumvirate collapses naturally. The Dahae’s northern territory and the lands of the southern Qidri would both be valuable acquisitions in this endeavour. Now… Forward, Parthia!

Internal turmoil has diminished your territories but, now that the Dacian tribes are once again united, the time has come to take them back. The Boii exploited your weakness mercilessly and should be driven from the region as a priority. Once they are taken care of, you may reclaim your lands on the Black Sea coast to open up new opportunities for trade and conquest. However, be wary of the threat from across the Danube. Your Thracian cousins nurse old wounds and, buoyed by their alliance with the Roman general, Mark Antony, may yet seek conflict. Let them come to face you on the battlefield, as Dacians live only to conquer!

At last the time has come to seize the fertile Gaulish lands that, until now, have proved so elusive. Your alliance with the Quadi will protect your advance and enable you to make short work of the obstructive Vindelici. In the past, the Gauls ran to their Roman masters for help – expect the Helvetii to do the same on this occasion. If you are confident in your ability to face both foes, attack now. Alternatively, spare this province until Octavian’s legions are distracted by the collapse of the Triumvirate. It is the time of the Marcomanni; to new lands and new wars!

Now you have the chance to surpass the exploits of your glorious predecessor. Alliance with Mark Antony and Lepidus, however tenuous, gives you the space to protect and extend your domains. Once again your Gaulish friends are menaced by migratory Germans - defeat them and take the chance to conquer their lands for Rome’s glory. Also, pay heed to Pompey, the son of your father’s enemy, whose fleet continues to menace your coast. Remember, however, that your ultimate goal is leadership of the Republic; when relations break down, this must be your focus to the exclusion of all else. Seize your birthright - seize the day!

Having received the lion’s share of the Republic and its challenges, you are locked into a deadly struggle with Parthia in the east. They wish to rob you of valuable client states; you may save them and counterattack deep into Parthian territory, or sacrifice these provinces to buy yourself time elsewhere. In the Balkans, your Thracian allies are threatened by deadly nomadic tribes from the north; invading the region will give you a springboard to Rome should your fragile Triumvirate collapse. This, after all, is your ultimate goal, and should be pursued with unswerving dedication. Greatness beckons you; follow its trail to the bitter end!

Hemmed in at the edge of the world by your nominal allies, Octavian and Mark Antony, you know that this uneasy peace cannot last. Still, it would be wise to avoid direct conflict with them for now. Focus on consolidating your position in Iberia by subduing the Cantabri and enlarging your African domain. The conquest of Pompey’s Mediterranean strongholds is a demanding task, but will give you a foothold in Octavian’s territory that may prove extremely valuable when the Triumvirate collapses. When this happens, as it inevitably must, the betrayals you suffered in the past will make victory all the sweeter!

From your central Mediterranean seat of power, nothing is beyond your reach. Tread carefully, however, for the closest shores are controlled by the Second Triumvirate, who hate and fear you. Attack now and you may face retribution from them all, so bide your time. Such a tenuous alliance will surely collapse and you can then pick off your adversaries one by one. Your useful strategic location could even be used to broker a deal with Mark Antony, as the enmity between you is surpassed only by mutual hatred of Octavian, heir to your oldest foe. Rise, son of Neptune! There will be a Pompeius Magnus once more!
Όταν τα πελάγη ελεγχθούν, η Κόρινθος θα αποκαλυφθεί ως η αληθινή δύναμη στην Ελλάδα!

Όταν οι Αθηναίοι αποδυναμωθούν, η Κόρινθος είναι ιδανικά τοποθετημένη για να αναλάβει τις νησιωτικές κτήσεις τους.
Καθώς οι αποικίες τους είναι διασκορπισμένες σε όλη την Ελλάδα, υπάρχουν πολλά για να υπερασπιστούν οι Κορίνθιοι. Η Όλυνθος χρειάζεται προστασία και οι Κερκυραίοι επαναστάτες πρέπει να συντριβούν.
Το ναυτικό των Αθηναίων μπορεί να είναι σπουδαίο, αλλά ήταν Κορίνθιοι μηχανικοί που εφηύραν τις τριήρεις που απαρτίζουν το στόλο τους.
Δεν ήρθε ο καιρός για την Βοιωτική Ηγεμονία επί της Ελλάδας;

Η Θεσσαλία είναι επίσης ώριμη για κατάκτηση. Παρότι είναι επί του παρόντος ουδέτεροι, φημολογείται ότι ευνοούν τους Αθηναίους. Μετά την κατάκτηση της, τα καλύτερα άλογα της Ελλάδας θα ανήκουν στο Κοινό.
Οι αθηναϊκές αποικίες στο βορά είναι αδύναμες σε σχέση με τη μητρόπολη, οπότε θα είναι ένας εύκολος στόχος.
Τώρα, ως σύμμαχος των ισχυρών Σπαρτιατών, οι Βοιωτοί μπορούν επιτέλους να πάρουν εκδίκηση.
Το Κοινό των Βοιωτών υπέφερε στα χέρια των Αθηναίων. Λίγο νωρίτερα από μια δεκαετία, προσπάθησαν να προσαρτήσουν κάποια εδάφη των Βοιωτών και αποτράπηκαν μόνο από την παρέμβαση των Σπαρτιατών.
Όταν το Λαύριο καταληφθεί, η Αθήνα θα είναι ο επόμενος στόχος. Είναι το κλειδί για την κυριαρχία επί όλων των Ελλήνων.

Οι Σπαρτιάτες σκοπεύουν να σακατέψουν τους Αθηναίους στη ξηρά, ώστε να μη μπορέσει το ναυτικό τους να γίνει πολύ μεγάλο. Αφού τα ορυχεία του Λαυρίου παρέχουν το μεγαλύτερο μέρος του εισοδήματος της πόλης και συνεπώς, και της ικανότητας τους να ναυπηγήσουν πλοία, η απώλεια τους θα ήταν καταστρεπτική.
Το 'ξύλινο τείχος' των Αθηναίων, ο στόλος τους, που εγγυάται την κυριαρχία τους στα πελάγη, δεν μπορεί να αντιμετωπίσει τους Σπαρτιάτες οπλίτες.
Η αλαζονεία των Αθηναίων έχει γίνει πολύ μεγάλη για να την ανεχθούν οι Σπαρτιάτες. Ωστόσο, η μεγαλύτερη δύναμη των Αθηναίων είναι επίσης και η μεγαλύτερη αδυναμία τους.
Οι Σπαρτιάτες έχουν δίκιο να μην εμπιστεύονται τους Αθηναίους. Σχεδόν δέκα χρόνια πριν, οι Αθηναίοι πολέμησαν ενάντια στους συμμάχους τους, τους Κορινθίους.

Είναι ζωτικής σημασίας οι Αθηναίοι να διατηρήσουν όλες τις πόλεις τους και να αντιμετωπίσουν την χερσαία στρατιωτική ισχύ των Σπαρτιατών με το εντυπωσιακό τους ναυτικό. Η κυριαρχία της Ελλάδας αναμένει τον νικητή.
Στα βόρεια, η Όλυνθος έχει γίνει στόχος. Μακριά από την πατρίδα, είναι ένας ώριμος στόχος για κατάκτηση.
Στα δυτικά, οι Κερκυραίοι έκαναν έκκληση στους Αθηναίους για βοήθεια ενάντια στη μητρόπολη τους. Ένας στόλος έχει αποσταλεί για να τους βοηθήσει.
Οι Αθηναίοι βρίσκονται ήδη σε πόλεμο· οι συγκρούσεις με τους Κορινθίους έχουν ξεκινήσει.
Ας μην ξεχνάμε τους Πέρσες. Η αυτοκρατορία τους ακόμα υφίσταται και παρακολουθεί στενά τις εξελίξεις στην Ελλάδα, για να εξασφαλίσει ότι καμιά από τις δυο ομάδες δε θα γίνει πολύ ισχυρή.
Καθώς οι δυο ισχυρές ομάδες βρίσκονται αντιμέτωπες, ο πόλεμος ελλοχεύει.
Ενάντια στην Αθηναϊκή Ηγεμονία, οι Σπαρτιάτες ανασυγκρότησαν την Πελοποννησιακή Συμμαχία με τους Κορινθίους και το Κοινό των Βοιωτών.

Είχαν δίκιο στις υποψίες τους· οι Αθηναίοι μετέτρεψαν τη συμμαχία που έφτιαξαν σε μια αυτοκρατορία υπό τον έλεγχο τους. Τώρα, δεν είναι πια ένα σύνολο ανεξάρτητων πόλεων, αλλά μία σειρά βάσεων για το ισχυρό ναυτικό τους.

Η Συμμαχία της Κορίνθου, που σχηματίστηκε για να πολεμήσει τους εισβολείς, δεν άντεξε. Έχοντας υποψίες για τις φιλοδοξίες των Αθηναίων, οι Σπαρτιάτες και άλλες μεγάλες πόλεις εγκατέλειψαν τη συμμαχία.
Σαράντα χρόνια πέρασαν από τις μεγάλες μας νίκες έναντι των Περσών. Θα έπρεπε να είναι η αρχή της χρυσής επόχης μας, όμως εμείς φιλονικούμε μεταξύ μας.
Η ιδρύτρια τόσων άλλων πόλεων θα γίνει η μεγαλυτερη από όλες!
To outflank the enemy, go around the ends of their line and attack their sides and rear. You will also need to engage their centre to hold them in place and stop them turning to face you.
Military access is a symbol of trust between two factions, allowing troops to move about and replenish in one another's territory without diplomatic penalties.

A straight line of units is not always the best formation. A kink, vee or step will create a point in the line where two of your units can engage one of theirs. Exploit this, but remember it works both ways.
The naturally occurring resources or cultural buildings that are this region's speciality are yet to be exploited to their full potential.

Flashing banners mean your line is wavering and the troops close to breaking and routing. Use your general's inspiration ability to keep them in the fight a little longer. Some elite infantry types can also inspire courage in nearby comrades.

This list shows all factions currently known to you, whether you can trade or are trading with them, their diplomatic status and current attitude towards you. It can be sorted by each of those headings.
A fight between two spear-equipped infantry units usually comes down to troop quality and numbers. Make sure you have local superiority - or send in some supporting troops.
When defending a river crossing it may be best to stand back in order to stay out of range of enemy missile troops. When their main force starts to cross, rush a couple of units up to stop them.
Pressing this button cancels orders and makes selected units or ships stop where they are. This is a quicker alternative to giving them a different order.

Your faction is bankrupt due to high army upkeep costs. All [[url:/manual/single-player/0017_enc_page_campaign_play_military_recruit]]recruitment[[/url]] and [[url:/manual/single-player/0045_enc_page_campaign_play_province_construction]]construction[[/url]] has been halted until funds are available. You could reduce upkeep costs by disbanding unused units.
One of your land trade routes is under attack from an enemy army. Without intervention they will continue to take your income for themselves!

Money can be offered to or demanded as reparations for war, tribute to avoid attack, or simply as an act of goodwill. If it is not part of a diplomatic deal you are brokering such payments are considered to be state gifts.

Generals can use their rally ability to raise the morale of any unit and try to stop routing troops running from the field - except those in a shattered state, who will always ignore the call to rally. Once activated, the cursor can be placed anywhere within the radius of the selected general's influence.
There is barely enough money in your treasury to cover costs. You can ensure your provinces are taxed effectively by ensuring their settlements are upgraded to the highest available levels.
If your army has superiority in terms of firepower you may be able to force a defender off the hill with missiles alone. Use all your ammunition before assaulting the hill.

Grab the enemy by the throat and then hit them in the vitals! It is the most basic strategy and is always valid. Have one part of your army hold the enemy in place while the rest manoeuvre to kill them.

Units with banners that have turned white are routing - they have broken and are running away, and won't follow any more of your orders. If positioned close by, your general may be able to rally these troops with his special ability. If successful you'll regain control of them.
There are currently no troops stationed in this region, leaving it open to conquest by an aggressive neighbour.

Some units are masters of concealment and can make themselves almost invisible in any terrain. Try putting these troops off to the side of your main force, where the enemy may not notice them. A surprise flank attack can then be launched once the battle has begun.

Wedge formation increases the violence of a cavalry charge. Intended to drive a wedge through the enemy unit and cause maximum casualties, this formation is also useful for charging through narrow gaps. Select wedge formation using the button on the battle control panel.

A cavalry unit moving quickly across the field of fire is not a sensible target for missile units. You may kill a few enemies, but better look instead for a tightly-packed target unit, one at a standstill, or coming head-on towards you.
This option is used to ask a faction to abandon their alliance with another, preventing dangerous coalitions from emerging against you.

This panel gives information about a building's effects, along with a detailed description of its function. Most buildings allow you to [[url:/manual/single-player/0045_enc_page_campaign_play_province_construction]]construct[[/url]] other, more advanced ones - so it's worth reading all the information here and checking the [[url:/home]]encyclopaedia[[/url]] too.

This panel shows you information about an allied, neutral or enemy [[url:/manual/single-player/0047_enc_page_campaign_play_characters]]character[[/url]]. His name, position on the map, character [[url:/manual/single-player/0052_enc_page_campaign_play_characters_traits]]traits[[/url]] and [[url:/manual/single-player/0051_enc_page_campaign_play_characters_skills]]skills[[/url]] relating to military abilities are all listed, along with details of any [[url:/manual/single-player/0053_enc_page_campaign_play_characters_ancillaries]]household[[/url]] members or objects.

This panel gives information about how a [[url:/manual/single-player/0039_enc_page_campaign_play_faction_technology]]technology's[[/url]] effects are applied, along with a detailed description of its function. Some technologies are essential for [[url:/manual/single-player/0045_enc_page_campaign_play_province_construction]]constructing[[/url]] certain buildings, so it's worth reading all the information here and checking the [[url:/home]]encyclopaedia[[/url]] too.
Wherever possible fight downhill. Whoever is higher has a great advantage.

Generals deploy their forces according to rank. A higher ranking general deploys after lower ranking ones, giving him the ability to view the deployment of a lower ranking opponent before committing his own troops.
The treasury indicates the amount of money currently in your faction's coffers and is displayed next to your projected income for the next turn and the current date.

[[url:/manual/single-player/0082_enc_page_battle_play_phase_conflict_groups]]Grouped[[/url]] units or ships can be set to one of several fixed group [[url:/manual/single-player/0081_enc_page_battle_play_phase_conflict_army_formations]]formations[[/url]]. Select a formation from the options presented to you. Move your mouse over each one to see what it does.
Forces that are not large enough to be effective could be destroyed if attacked, so it is prudent to merge any fragments together. Select one and right-click on another to merge with it.
Hiding stronger units to the rear may entice the enemy into a rash attack. They can then be brought up quickly to attack the weakest point.

Following capture of a [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]settlement[[/url]], local unrest may require a garrison remains while any damaged buildings are [[url:/manual/single-player/0045_enc_page_campaign_play_province_construction\#enc_text_manual_actions_campaign_construction_repair]]repaired[[/url]] and public order is stabilised.
The movement speed button is used to instantly increase or decrease the speed of units or ships. This is useful for going somewhere in a hurry, but using it too much causes fatigue.

When in [[url:/manual/single-player/0092l_enc_page_battle_play_interface_skirmish]]skirmish[[/url]] mode, troops avoid getting into [[url:/manual/single-player/0092j_enc_page_battle_play_interface_melee]]melee[[/url]] by keeping their distance from the enemy and attacking with arrows, javelins or sling shot. When a unit of missile troops is selected the skirmish mode button will appear. It can be toggled on or off.

Winning a battle isn't just about greater numbers, the balance of units and the general's ability are important factors also. Look at the strength ratio and any reinforcement information before committing yourself, but beware, if you are attacked it may not be possible to avoid combat! The buttons on this panel represent your battle options. Mouse over each one to see what it does.

Every army, fleet or agent can reveal information about rival armies, fleets and settlements in their immediate proximity or within their line of sight. The level of detail available depends on the type of character who is spying, so, for instance, spies are able to reveal more than champions.

Your port has been blockaded by an enemy fleet. This does not affect your ability to build new ships or repair existing combat-damaged ships, but all trade income through it will be suspended for the life of the blockade. Attack the enemy fleet to break out and restore trade.

Terrain and settlements that are known to your faction but to which you have no line of sight are covered by the fog of war. Use your agents and forces to reveal the machinations of your rivals before they act against you!
There is an armed rebellion occurring in a neighbouring region! This wave of insurrection may reach your territory, guard against it by increasing garrison sizes or reducing taxes.

The [[url:/manual/single-player/0092b_enc_page_battle_play_interface_compass]]manoeuvre[[/url]] compass is used for fine-tuning orders. It can be used to direct a unit, ship or group straight ahead, or turn left or right.

Units are [[url:/manual/single-player/0017_enc_page_campaign_play_military_recruit]]recruited[[/url]], or mustered, directly by a general in the field. Select the recruitment tab, then left-click on a unit to add it to the queue. Left-click again to remove it. When ready, units automatically appear in the army of the general who mustered them. It is not possible to move a [[url:/manual/single-player/0018_enc_page_campaign_play_military_stances\#enc_text_manual_actions_campaign_stances_muster]]mustering[[/url]] army without first cancelling the recruitment process.

This panel shows statistical information about the selected [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]province[[/url]]. The right-hand section shows the elements affecting, and status of, [[url:/manual/single-player/0044a_enc_page_campaign_play_province_public_order]]public order[[/url]] and the left-hand section shows the factors contributing to the wealth of the local and [[url:/manual/single-player/0036_enc_page_campaign_play_faction]]faction[[/url]] economy. Use the the checkbox in the top left of the panel to exempt it from taxation.

As the main administrative centre in a [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]region[[/url]], the settlement contains both [[url:/manual/single-player/0046_enc_page_campaign_play_province_trade_finance]]trade[[/url]] and [[url:/manual/single-player/0020_enc_page_campaign_play_military]]military[[/url]] buildings. Settlements are the main consumer of [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]food[[/url]] supplies in a province, so it is vitally important to keep food-production buildings upgraded to avoid shortages.

This army is now in a position to [[url:/manual/single-player/0022_enc_page_campaign_play_military_ambush]]ambush[[/url]] passing enemies. However, be aware that hidden enemies can ambush your own armies in just the same way!

When using light infantry or skirmishers to force light troops to retreat behind their lines, be careful not to chase them too far. Do not risk getting dragged into a fight with their frontline units.

Group selected units or ships together here. [[url:/manual/single-player/0082_enc_page_battle_play_phase_conflict_groups]]Groups[[/url]] are useful for giving identical orders via a single command. You can reselect the group by clicking on its numbered tab, or by pressing the corresponding number key. Press this button again to dissolve the group.
The balance of power bar tracks the relative strength of your force against that of your enemy.

This panel is used to manually merge armies or fleets in order to assemble the strongest possible force. Click on the unit or ship you wish to move, then click on the tick button to move it from one force to another. It is possible to select several units or ships at a time.

[[url:/manual/single-player/0092f_enc_page_battle_play_interface_fire]]Fire-at-will[[/url]] for missiles can be toggled on or off. Keeping it toggled off will help preserve ammunition, but then your units or ships will only fire when specifically ordered.
Mines facilitate the harvesting of underground resources such as gold and iron for trade and weapon-making purposes.
When outnumbered, make sure you keep open the option of withdrawal. This will help you to reduce casualties if the battle is being lost.
Cavalry troops make an excellent flanking force. They can move fast around the edge of the enemy formation and strike the sides or rear, but a clever opponent will be ready for this.

[[url:/manual/single-player/0044a_enc_page_campaign_play_province_public_order\#enc_text_manual_public_order_rebellions]]Rebellions[[/url]] grow in strength over time the more they are left unchecked. You must always act quickly in these instances lest the rebels may take over the [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]province[[/url]].
One of your sea trade routes is under attack from an enemy fleet! If you do not intervene they will continue to take your income for themselves!

Pressing the space bar on your keyboard after orders have been issued displays the positions your units will move to as a shadow on the battlefield. Use this as a reference when deploying your forces.
Deploying on a hill is always a good idea. Being uphill gives your troops a melee advantage, and climbing it will tire the enemy. Shooting downhill helps too.

Right-click to [[url:/manual/single-player/0019_enc_page_campaign_play_military_movement]]move[[/ur]] your army or fleet to any part of the highlighted area. You can [[url:/manual/single-player/0016_enc_page_campaign_play_military_attack]]attack[[/url]] by right-clicking on a rival faction's army or [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]settlement[[/url]]. Board a fleet by right-clicking on the sea, your army will automatically join a troop transport. Merge with a friendly army or fleet by moving onto the same spot.
Information about any selected character, army, fleet, port or settlement is displayed here, including their constituent units or ships.

Useful natural resources are present in many regions. Their exploitation increases the income available through trade, and in some cases improves the quality of the weapons and armour that can be produced. Build or improve farms, mines and region speciality buildings to get the most from the available resources.

Attrition is the loss of men due to desertion, disease, etc. An army will generally suffer [[url:/manual/single-player/0026_enc_page_campaign_play_military_replenish]]attrition[[/url]] when in desert or extremely cold conditions unless it is native to that part of the world. Ship crews and armies transported by sea may also suffer attrition when in deep waters.

The road system within a [[url:/manual/single-player/0044_enc_page_campaign_play_province_regions]]region[[/url]] will improve as prosperity increases. Better quality roads increase the movement range of the [[url:/manual/single-player/0016_enc_page_campaign_play_military_attack]]armies[[/url]] and agents who use them, as well as the line of sight from both the road and the nearest settlement. They also improve the chances of detecting enemy [[url:/manual/single-player/0047_enc_page_campaign_play_characters]]agents[[/url]].

Your general has the ability to raise the morale of nearby troops from his own army, although not those of any allies present. If placed near a unit that is wavering his presence may give his men the resolve they need to stay in the fight.
At any time during a conflict, this option can be used to request that a faction joins a war that you are fighting, meaning you can look for new allies to help if the conflict is not going your way.

The enemy will try to either sneak past your defences or rush them by force of arms. Use missile troops to kill approaching enemies and melee troops to kill those that get to the plaza. They will try to wipe out all defenders, and if your men rout en masse then the battle is over.

In order to gain control of a garrisoned and fortified settlement it is often necessary to lay siege. During a siege your troops surround the settlement and will either attempt to starve the defenders into capitulation or launch a direct assault.
Always try to present a solid wall of troops to the enemy. Large gaps between units will let them flood through and behind your units, which would be disastrous.

Take the initiative in battle by making manoeuvres the enemy must respond to. Even if you don't follow it through, they'll be so busy countering your moves they'll have no time to make any of their own.
The boarding button orders your ship to close with the target vessel and sends an armed group aboard to capture it. This action can be cancelled at any time by issuing another order.
There are not enough funds in your treasury to build anything this turn. Increase taxation and trade, or disband redundant armed forces to raise your short-term income.

The battle timer shows how much time is left before the battle ends. The attacker must rout or destroy the defender within the time limit or lose the battle. To claim victory the defender has only to keep the attacker at bay, so can still win even if outnumbered.

The best admirals adapt their tactics to the given situation. Take advantage of fog or heavy smoke to hide small or heavily damaged ships. This makes the enemy's job more difficult, a factor which can often prove crucial during the course of a battle.
There is often an advantage in ordering your infantry to counter-charge an attacking formation. The trick is to leave it until the last moment, so your own lines are not broken.

Intrigues

Each agent has three attributes - authority, cunning and zeal. They are key to the agent development, as actions and skills they possess scale as their attributes improve. Each skill from an agent's skill tree grants points to one of the three attributes and carries with it effects which become stronger as the attribute is raised. If an effect scales with a particular attribute, its tooltip will contain that information in brackets – for instance, (cunning-based) means that the effect improves with higher cunning.

The formerly powerful Roman Empire crumbles before your eyes! Fulfil the dream of the Marcomanni - lead them south towards Noreia, then plunder Pannonia along with the other nearby Roman cities. First, however, consolidate your hold over Hercynia - a land you share with the Quadi to the east and the Alemanni to the west. Either negotiate alliances or spill their blood! The north is home to many ambitious chieftains, so remain vigilant against betrayal by people who call themselves your brothers. Remember, Wodanaz favours the brave... and the brave alone!

Agents have three attributes - authority, cunning and zeal. For champions, zeal increases killing power, cunning strengthens settlement raids and authority betters unit training and motivation of villagers. For dignitaries, zeal helps bribe units and spread disorder, cunning increases settlement income, and authority enhances unit upkeep and enemy agent recruitment. For spies, zeal improves delaying other agents and food theft, cunning affects army speed, and authority boosts the protection from enemy agents.

Embezzle Funds: \n\nThough frowned upon in other ages, corruption was rampant at the height of Roma's ascendancy. It was hard to distinguish bribe from a gift based on legislation and certain people would always be prone to embezzle the funds they oversaw…

Emperor Aurelian, you face a crisis most dire! Barbarian hordes swarm along our borders and usurpers lay in wait for an attempt to seize power. From your capital at Sirmium, you must hold off invading barbarians and prepare to meet the major contenders - Palmyra to the south-east and Gallic Rome, to the west. Act quickly! March to Latium and seize control of Rome itself. Remember, there are territories in Asia Minor, Numidia and Mauretania still loyal to you - priceless allies in these dark days. In the name of Sol Invictus, go forth and restore our world!

The skill trees of generals, admirals and agents have been reworked with new skills that allow for greater specialisation. Generals and admirals can become masters of battle, cunning strategists or a pillar of authority for their troops. Agents can learn to disrupt armies and agents, exact boons from enemy settlements, or improve the capabilities of miltiary forces and encampments. Character skill trees also have differences per culture - Barbarian, Hellenic, Eastern and Roman generals can be developed in different ways.

The great Odaenathus of Palmyra is dead, yet his legacy lives on. Be quick and march into Egypt, for the fertile lands of the Nile can feed our entire populace. For now, your southern border is safe, as Nabataeans and Lakhmids offer their goods and friendship. To the east, the Sassanids and their satrapies carefully observe your every move, yet have kept their weapons sheathed thus far. Meanwhile, Roman forces at Galatia, fearing Palmyra and her growing might, stand ready to declare war. Your position is precarious, yet under your ambitious rule Palmyra shall prosper!

You are the third Sassanid Shahanshah - the stars have ordained that you will eclipse your great predecessors Ardashir and Shapur! Your satraps protect most of the borders, leaving you free to wage war against the desert kingdoms to the south-west, while maintaining an uneasy truce with Palmyra. The Roman provinces to the north-west are an enticing yet difficult prize. You also need to deal with the Dahae, who threaten both your lands and those of your satraps. As for the satraps themselves, be wary of Sakastan, for the Sakas are descended from a freedom-loving nomadic tribe prone to revolts.
Entice: \n\nEvery person has their price. Combined with insight into their interests, their views and allegiance may change.

Intrigues: \n\nOnly the strongest of characters remain in the peoples' tales through the ages. Antiquity was a stage for displays of psyche, interpersonal relations and public dilemmas. The parties and the noble families of the time were intertwined, more in some cultures than in others. Thus, a constant strife for dominance among the different factions of the elite developed, for one's worth was synonymous with one's standing.

Spread Rumors: \n\nPersonal stature, especially of a family patriarch, was symbolic of his social position and power in the family. A few words, however, from the wrong source to the right ears could easily strip a person of their livelihood or even their life.

The Saxoni have been braving the seas to raid coastal settlements for generations. As other Germanic barbarians gather around the mangled body of the Roman Empire, poised for the kill, the time of Saxon glory is at hand! In order to fully exploit your people's natural maritime power, a proper port is required. This is bound to bring you into conflict with your German brethren to the south. Once a harbour is secured, the Saxon raiding fleets can sail south along Gallic shores or even invade the lands of Roman Britain. Cast off to greatness!

Send Emissary: \n\nIf you can't appeal to the public based on your actions, you can always do it through their stomachs. Indeed, many nobles held huge feasts, taking place over days and costing a fortune. People were even given extra rations and allowances, which bought their gratitude, as well as their continued survival.

Noble Tetricus, there are threats aplenty! To the east, over the Rhine, Germanic tribes are ready to cross the river and invade. Thwart their incursions and then strike back to prevent future ones. Once the eastern borders are secured, prudence dictates that a march towards the city of Rome will strengthen your position. Only then should you challenge Emperor Aurelian, who reigns over Pannonia and nearby provinces. Be mindful that, while Britannia remains loyal, Lusitania and Hispania to the south suffer from delusions of independence. Watch them closely as they may brew betrayal!

Champions are seasoned military veterans, hired to perform military acts as solitary agents apart from their army. They can attempt assassinations on enemy characters, attack enemy garrisons, train military units or influence a province's population to be happy or angry. Through their experience as agents, champions can learn new skills such as demoralising enemy troops, laying traps for opposing agents, improving recruitment of new units and causing rebellion within enemy settlements.

The Veneti have defended their land vehemently against any would-be invaders - their neighbours are well aware of Venetian bravery and the exceptional qualities of the Venetian horse. However, it remains paramount to always keep a watchful eye on your borders. To the north, the mountain-dwelling Raeti might decide to try their luck at any point. The same is true of the unruly Gauls, who prefer raiding to farming, and are known for their bloodlust rather than their goodwill. Come what may, mighty Diomedes of old protects the Veneti, and their sword-arms are throbbing with his strength!

Suicide: \n\nOne couldn't just commit suicide in Roma. The candidate was expected to appeal to the Senate; if his reasons were deemed fair (which was rarely the case) he was given hemlock, the go-to poison plant of the age. Such practices were far less common elsewhere, however.

Educate: \n\nPersonal education was important for the elite, who sought to expand their offspring’s horizons. Foreign tutelage was expensive and only available to the highest nobility, but there were designated places of learning, like the Platonic Academy, Aristotle's Peripatetic School and the Museion in Alexandria, among others.

Dignitaries are influential nobles who can quietly turn the tide of war in your favour through eloquence, bribery and administration. They can bribe enemy units into disbanding, recruit rival agents to your cause, decrease the costs of armies and settlements, steal income from enemy provinces, and drive an enemy settlement to revolt. Through experience as agents, dignitaries can learn to grant loyalty to political parties, develop diplomatic ties with other factions, and bribe commanders into joining your ranks.

Gather Support: \n\nA leader's personal motivation and charisma can often mean more than any cause. Caesar marched into Rome with the support of his Legions, as had Sulla and others before him. In an age of skirmishes between different parties and factions, the shift of power during peacetime was representative of the support one would receive in battle.

In the past, the Gothi laid waste to the Roman provinces of Dacia and Thracia, reaching as far as Achaia and Asia; you must eclipse the glorious raids of the past! Behold Odessos and Apollonia Pontica - their riches are ripe for the taking. In Dacia, capturing the Roman fortress of Zarmizegetusa would open the gates to Pannonia and Illyricum. Remember, the Buri to the north could be persuaded into alliance, while the Roxolani nomads of Dacia require a tougher approach. Be wary of the Heruli and Bosporou to the east, for they will exploit any weakness you show.

Spies are expert scouts and masters of clandestine activities who can discover and delay threats before they strike. They can impede enemy armies and agents, improve an army's ability to traverse terrain, reveal the location of a faction's military resources, steal a settlement's food, and protect against enemy agent actions. Through experience as agents, spies can learn to poison armies, assassinate characters, steal technological research, burn an army's ammunition, and disrupt enemy recruitment and construction.
Praise: \n\nIt takes more than courage to speak well of a person you dislike; it takes talent for them to welcome it.

The Iolei of Sardinia are an ancient and indomitable people. Once they shared the isle of Sardinia with other tribes of the same blood. Then the Carthaginians came and claimed the coastland for themselves. The time has come to rise and drive the insolent invaders into the very sea they came from! The Balari have often swore that they are brothers to the Iolei, yet, when push comes to shove, they may hesitate. Either awaken their strength in the upcoming fight or conquer them and take their land! Sardinia is the first arena of battle - be worthy of Sardus Pater!

Make Heir: \n\nAugustus called himself not an emperor, but 'Princeps' (literally 'First Citizen'). However, being Caesar's adopted son, he was often referred to as such. Later generations adopted 'Augustus' for the progenitor and 'Caesar' for his successor. Emperors often adopted others into their family to ensure their continued rule and support.
Usurp Legacy: \n\nWhen a man of power loses his grip, his underlings' craving for the laurel wreath, as each of them knows their success is not guaranteed.

Flirt: \n\nYour husband too will be present at my banquet; I pray it’s his last meal, that man of yours!… When he sinks on the couch, as you recline at the table, there being the face of modesty itself, secretly touch my foot!"- from Ars Amatoria, by Ovid (43BC - AD17)"

Rome is at war! The Etruscans of Veii have been our enemies for many years and since peace is out of the question, we must bring them down by force of arms. The proud Volsci of Latium are carefully observing the conflict and will undoubtedly strike should we provoke their ire. In such a conflict, we might try to ally with the Hernici. Meanwhile, rumour has it that a new threat is stirring beyond the lands of the cowardly Sabines and docile Umbri. Be mindful, yet brave! May Mars watch over you!

The Samnites are famous for their honour and courage. In recent years, they have maintained peace with their Frentani and Paeligni kinsmen while forcing Daunian and Lucanian raiders to recognise the superiority of Samnite swordsmen. As the hills of Samnium grow overpopulated, they must settle elsewhere, yet the ancient ritual of Ver Sacrum is hardly an option. This is why the Samnites must march into Campania: to claim its verdant pastures and rich ports. Once the Greeks are driven away and their land has been conquered, the Samnites could turn their gaze towards Latium and the city of Rome beyond.

Secure Promotion: \n\nThe Cursus Honorum was one of the most elaborate, well-structured office tier of the time. A similar hierarchy existed in other societies also, as most well-regarded offices came with certain political powers and obligations. Pushing oneself up the ladder inevitably prevented others from doing so, making more enemies than friends in the process.

For years our people have lived in the shadow of mighty Carthage to the north, but times are changing - something big is happening across the sea that may yet change our fate. We must be ready to take any opportunity arising from this delicate situation. To prepare well, we should look to unite our Berber cousins spread across northern Africa. The Gaetuli are sensible people and honest warriors; Garamantians, on the other hand, are unpredictable and seem very selfish. At the end of the day, the tribes must be united if the future is to be secured - either with the olive branch or by the sword!
Do a Favour: \n\nA helping hand is rarely turned back… especially when said hand has pulled certain strings...

For centuries, the people of Kush have competed with their powerful Egyptian neighbours. Since Alexander conquered their lands we are the only protectors of ancient traditions in the region. However, it is time we took back what is ours and saved Egyptian people from Greek tyranny. Beware, however, the threat to the south; the treacherous kingdom of Axum will take any opportunity to catch us off-guard. We would also do well to take part in the lucrative spice trade blossoming beyond the Red Sea. May Amani guide your head and Apedemak your hand!
Send Gift: \n\nMake others appreciate what they haven’t got, and gain prestige for the gesture.
Assassinate: \n\nIn Roma, political assassination was the go-to tactic for getting rid of your opponents. If only it wasn't so obvious…

We are the children of Almaqah! We don't seek to rob others of their riches because we grow our own. Centuries ago, our engineers built the great dam, and we have since turned the desert into a garden. Over the years, we have learned to live and trade with our neighbours to the north, but there are also those, such as the Gerrhaea to the northeast, whose greed and envy might force us into an unwanted war. Under the circumstances, it would be wise to seek the alliance of the friendly Mascat to the east, and try and expand our trade operation to the west.

Political Marriage: \n\nWomen of noble families were often wed at a very young age, preferably to a young man of higher status. This strengthened the bonds between families often entangled in politics or business commitments. Hence, divorce was not that uncommon.
Divorce: \n\nThere is no shame in this – certain ties are not meant to be, but there are consequences for severing them.

Seek Spouse: \n\nRomulus and his men abducted the Sabine women with trickery, but promised them marriage with the benefits of property, citizenship and children. This founded the basic principles of marriage in Roma, and while abduction was still observed as a means of acquiring a wife, the union itself became institutionalised and defined by law.

The people of Nabataea have always been honest traders, keeping the flow of valuable spices to all corners of the world. In return, we learn from the people of the west and share in the vast riches of the east. This trade has allowed us to flourish where nobody else could. Naturally, our success has attracted the envy of the greedy Seleucids to the north. Beware these eastern Greeks because, like their armies, their satrapies are numerous and they can draw on widespread support should the need arise. Seek alliance with the Qidri and your other trade partners to the south and west. Fear not, for Dhu Shara is with us!
Adopt: \n\nAdoption in antiquity was mainly used to ensure a male heir, show appreciation or bring a person into the family for economic or similar needs.

Many years ago, King Bellovesus led several Gallic tribes across the Alps. The Insubres were among the first and they founded the formidable city of Mediolanon. Now, they are surrounded by tribes fierce and treacherous, such as the Lepontii and Raeti of the northern highlands. Gauls inhabit the plains south of Mediolanon; their chieftains could easily forego the bonds of blood due to unbridled avarice. The Ligurians are also a serious force, as their taciturn warriors are eager to avenge any aggression tenfold, even an imagined slight. Despite all this, opportunities for prosperity abound!

Provoke: \n\nSenators had the right to verbally challenge opponents during their speeches, and political rivalries were enjoyed by the masses, who loved to take sides. Poets, town-criers and gossips might be deployed to assert one vision over another, and all this could start with a well-timed satirical comment.

The fearsome Alani have always desired complete dominance over the Scythian steppes. To achieve it, first you must deal with the Iastae tribe, either through alliance or subjugation. Then, your swift riders can speed into Caucasia, where soldiers are weak but coffers are full. The kingdom of Bosporou, with its trading ports and walled cities, is another tempting target for the wrath of the steppe peoples. Lands bring riches, riches bring power and, in time, the hooves of your Alani steeds will trample mighty Rome itself!

For Dionysius of Syracuse, power is only a tool with which to gain more power. Having consolidated his grip over the magnificent polis and nearby cities, the tyrant is preparing to unite all Greek communities in Sicily one way or another. Only in this way will Syracuse be able to thwart the threat of the intolerable Carthaginian invaders, who defile Sicilian soil with their presence. Once they are forced out for good, Dionysius can turn his attention towards Magna Graecia, home of yet more Greeks  - they will be forced to acknowledge his supremacy!

Of all the Gallic tribes that crossed the Alps, the Senones were the last. They have since reached the Adriatic coast and conquered some land of their own; now their chief, Brennus, ponders his next move. To the north are the Boii - wild and unpredictable, yet kinsmen nonetheless. To the south, is the dominion of Etruscans and Umbri - idle and slow peoples, as rich as they are complacent. Their warriors are no match for Senone swordsmen, who are ready to march to hell if there is loot to be had!

Organize Games: \n\nIt was a common feat among the ancients to make a public display of their riches by organising events such as public games, performances, etc. Intentions varied but, in the end, it was the common folk who were appeased by ‘bread and circuses’.
Insult: \n\nEverything you say is so unbearably boring, by Hercules, that it’s murder by monotony." - Plautus (c. 250-184BC)"

The ancient kingdom of Armenia, conquered by Shapur I, has thus became dominated by the Sassanids. Overseen by Shahanshah Hormizd, you are free to pursue an expansion of the Armenian sphere of influence. Your plans need to take into account the war with the Romans of Lydia, to the west. To the south lie the lands of the Palmyrene Queen Zenobia, who could yet be a precious ally or a terrible foe. At the same time, Christian refugees from abroad flock to the city of Arsamosata, and must be dealt with by one way or another.
Improve Relations: \n\nThe means to acquire one's approval may not always be moral but ought to be fruitful, whether in a complicated shift of powers or through simple bribery.

The city of Taras is named after the son of Poseidon and considers the sea-god to be its founder. Currently, Taras' importance and influence has grown over nearby areas, but so have threats from nearby. The Iapygian tribes of Appulia and Calabria both covet the wealth of Taras and fear its hoplites, who are said to be descended from the Spartans. The Lucani people to the north also need to be closely watched, as their fickle nature might make them suddenly aggressive. All is not grim, however, as with proper incentives other Greek poleis on the southern coast of Magna Graecia may be willing to lend their aid.

Send Diplomat: \n\nIt is a great achievement for a politician to represent his country in foreign affairs. One can use the situation to promote personal interests or lose his head to the wrong combination of words and circumstances…

Of all the glorious Etruscan cities, Tarchuna shines as an emerald atop a pile of pearls. Its vast and fertile lands are home to many artisans, traders and artists. Though their skills are much envied by the other Etruscans, it is unlikely that this envy will lead to bloodshed. Only the city of Veii is the black sheep in the Etruscan flock; its king wages a pointless war against the Romans and there is no telling what the limits of his aggression will be. Great care is required - if the Veientines, or anyone else, conquers Tarchuna, all will be lost!
Leisure Time: \n\nEveryone needs some quiet time in the outskirts, at the villa, or even abroad, if funds allow... and don't forget to bring back souvenirs!

Almost sixty years have passed since the campaigns of Septimius Severus against the Caledoni. Since the great Emperor died, no further attempts to subdue them have been made. Now, sensing the weakened state of Roman affairs, you should prepare to reclaim the land of Britannia, that rightfully belongs to the Celtic people. The Ebdani cannot remain idle during the coming struggle - aiding your armies seems the only honourable choice open to them, and also the only wise one. If, of course, they prove treacherous, do not hesitate to swiftly eradicate them!
